logo: PSEG (Public Service Enterprise Group) with tagline "We make things work for you." Graphic Elements : ‚Ä¢ Circular orange emblem with white radiating lines resembling a sunburst, positioned to the left. ‚Ä¢ Bold black text "PSEG" with a smaller ampersand (&) between "S" and "G". ‚Ä¢ Tagline in italicized font below the company name: "We make things work for you." Layout & Dimensions : ‚Ä¢ Emblem and text are horizontally aligned. ‚Ä¢ Tagline is directly beneath the company name, left-justified. Analysis : ‚Ä¢ The sunburst emblem suggests energy or power, aligning with PSEG‚Äôs identity as an energy company. ‚Ä¢ The use of bold and italic fonts differentiates the company name from the tagline, enhancing brand recognition. Total amount due: $67.09 Please pay by: July 6, 2020 Your energy bill ! Message Center This bill reflects changes in the Supply and Delivery portions of your bill, effective June 1, 2020. The change in the Supply portion of your bill is a result of the statewide supply auction that was approved by the BPU on February 5, 2020. The change in the Delivery portion of your bill is a result of a small decrease to the Non-Utility Generation Charge. As a result of these changes, a typical residential customer who receives electric supply from PSE&G and uses 6,920 kilowatt-hours per year will see an average monthly increase of $5.57 or 4.1%. Tariff information may also be found by visiting pseg.com. Your safety is our top priority. Know what to do if you smell gas. Natural gas smells like rotten eggs. If you smell gas, leave the area immediately, and call 911 or PSE&G at 800-880-PSEG. Learn more at pseg.com/gassafety. Technical Details : ‚Ä¢ No scale bar, magnification, or scientific modality present. ‚Ä¢ The orange icon resembles a ‚Äúno entry‚Äù or ‚Äúprohibited‚Äù symbol, commonly used for alerts or warnings in user interfaces. Spatial Relationships : ‚Ä¢ Icon is left-aligned, followed by the bolded label, then the date. ‚Ä¢ All elements are horizontally arranged on a white background. Analysis : ‚Ä¢ The image communicates an upcoming meter reading scheduled for July 17, 2020, with the orange icon likely indicating a pending or alert status. ‚Ä¢ No additional interactive or data elements are present. How to contact us 1-800-436-PSEG (7734) Customer Service: 7am to 8pm Mon-Fri, 7am to 5pm Sat Emergencies / Outages / WorryFree Services: 24/7 TTY for the hearing impaired: 1-800-225-0072 - ‚Ä¢ Visit pseg.com/myaccount to access your account anytime - ‚Ä¢ Text us. Register for MyAlerts by texting REG to 4PSEG(47734) > Text OUT to report an outage. - ‚Ä¢ facebook.com/pseg twitter.com/psegdelivers Bill date: June 19, 2020 For the period: May 19, 2020 to June 17, 2020 Summary : This image displays account information for Edith Avella, including an account number and a service address. photo: Scene Overview : ‚Ä¢ Main subject: Account details for Edith Avella. ‚Ä¢ Setting: Digital or printed document, white background, black and orange text/icons. ‚Ä¢ Perspective: Straight-on, cropped to show only the relevant information. ‚Ä¢ Composition: Left side shows account number with folder icon; right side shows service address with house icon. ‚Ä¢ Colour palette: Black text, orange icons. Technical Details : ‚Ä¢ Account number: 70 023 651 18. ‚Ä¢ Service address: 214 KIPP AVE APT C, HASBROUCK HEIGHTS NJ 07604-1932. ‚Ä¢ Name: Edith Avella. ‚Ä¢ Icons: Orange folder (account number), orange house (service address). ‚Ä¢ No scale bar, magnification, or scientific modality. Spatial Relationships : ‚Ä¢ Account number and service address are presented side-by-side, separated by whitespace. ‚Ä¢ Icons are placed to the left of their respective text blocks. Analysis : ‚Ä¢ The image is designed to clearly present key account and address information for a specific individual, using icons for quick visual identification of each data type. ‚Ä¢ No additional data, patterns, or anomalies are present beyond the displayed information. Company Name & Tagline : ‚Ä¢ The logo displays "PSEG" in large, bold black letters. ‚Ä¢ The ampersand "&" is styled and placed between "PS" and "G". ‚Ä¢ Below the company name, the tagline reads: "We make things work for you." Graphic Elements : ‚Ä¢ To the left of the text, there is a circular orange-red emblem featuring a radiating white starburst pattern. Design & Layout : ‚Ä¢ The logo is horizontally oriented, with the emblem on the left and the text on the right. ‚Ä¢ The text is black, while the emblem uses a gradient of orange-red with white rays. ‚Ä¢ The background is plain white. Analysis : ‚Ä¢ The logo combines a bold, professional typeface with a dynamic, energetic emblem, suggesting reliability and energy-related services. The tagline reinforces a customer-focused message. If you or a member of your household rely on electricity to operate life sustaining equipment, please notify PSE&G. For more information, visit **pseg.com/life** or call **1-800-436-PSEG**. There is still time to get help paying your energy bills. Apply for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP). Submit a program application online, by fax, or through the mail by July 31, 2020. Call 1-800-510-3102, or visit pseg.com/help to find out where to apply. PSE&G can help you save energy and money with rebates of up to $100 on smart thermostats. A smart thermostat can help reduce energy bills by up to 10% annually, and many offer on-the-go control from a smartphone or tablet. Install a smart thermostat in your home and start saving this summer! To learn more, go to pseg.com/marketplace1. Don't miss your meter reading If you'll be away on your meter reading day, log in to MyAccount at pseg.com or call 1-800-622-0197 before your scheduled date, to submit your reading. Electric & Gas Rate Information For news about PSE&G's rate filing and upcoming public hearings visit www.pseg.com/pseandgfilings. Under applicable tax law, the State Sales and Use Tax and corporate business tax are imposed upon the energy you have used. Page 2 of 4 IT‚ÄôS **YOUR BILL.** HOW YOU PAY IS **YOUR CHOICE.** My Account Make a payment anytime from a checking or savings account stored in My Account. Visit pseg.com/myaccount Mobile: Download our Mobile App "PSE&G" Pay by text: Text PAY to 4PSEG (47734) Voice: Ask Alexa [checkbox icon] Automatic Bill Pay Automatic payments from your bank. Skip checks and stamps. Never worry about due dates. Enroll at: pseg.com/autopay [inline micro-figure: credit card icon] Credit Card Pay your bill with a credit card online or by phone. Because we don't use customer rates to subsidize the cost of this service, there is a fee. My Account: pseg.com/myaccount **Phone:** 1-888-575-6273 ‚òéÔ∏è Phone Bank Account: 1-800-553-7734 Credit Card: 1-888-575-6273 By Mail Make your check payable to PSE&G and write your account number on your check. When you pay by check, you authorize PSE&G to make a one-time electronic fund transfer from your account, in the amount of your check. If you prefer not to authorize us, call 1-800-436-PSEG. In Person Payments are accepted at any customer service center or authorized location. Locations can be found at: pseg.com/csc GO PAPERLESS! To sign up visit pseg.com/paperless üå± EDITH AVELLA Your account number: 7002365118 Invoice Number: 600906626509 logo: # Details of your gas charges Your rate: Residential Service Gas-Heating - RSG (HTG) Meter # 3113676 Usage Estimated reading Jun 17, 2020 9200 ~~Less~~ Estimated reading May 18, 2020 9183 Difference 17 Converted to CCF x 1.012 17.204 Converted to therms x 1.035 17.806 Total gas you used in 30 days 17.806 therms Delivery charges Monthly service charge $8.62 Charges for delivering gas to you: 17.806 therms x $0.356621 $6.35 Total gas delivery charges $14.97 Supply charges Cost of gas supplied by PSE&G: 17.806 therms x $0.320117 $5.70 Total gas supply charges $5.70 Total gas charges $20.67 Summary : This figure shows the average daily gas usage (in therms) and average daily temperature (in degrees Fahrenheit) from June 2019 to June 2020, highlighting seasonal variation and estimated readings. bar and line chart: # Title & Axes : ‚Ä¢ Title: "How much gas are you using?" ‚Ä¢ Left Y-axis: Therms (average daily usage, range: 0 to 8) ‚Ä¢ Right Y-axis: Temperature (average daily temperature, range: 0¬∞ to 80¬∞) ‚Ä¢ X-axis: Months from June 2019 to June 2020 (labels: Jun 2019, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct, Nov, Dec, Jan 2020, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun 2020) # Data Points : ‚Ä¢ Orange bars: Average daily gas usage (therms) for each month. ‚Äì Jun 2019: ~0 therms ‚Äì Jul: ~0 therms ‚Äì Aug: ~0.5 therms ‚Äì Sep: ~0.5 therms ‚Äì Oct: ~0.5 therms ‚Äì Nov: ~1 therm ‚Äì Dec: ~2.5 therms ‚Äì Jan 2020: ~2 therms ‚Äì Feb: ~2 therms ‚Äì Mar: ~1.5 therms ‚Äì Apr: ~1.5 therms ‚Äì May: ~1 therm ‚Äì Jun 2020: ~0.5 therms ‚Ä¢ Grey line: Average daily temperature (¬∞F) for each month. ‚Äì Peaks in summer (~80¬∞), declines to winter lows (~40¬∞), rises again in spring. ‚Ä¢ "E" above bars: Indicates estimated readings for all months. # Design Encodings : ‚Ä¢ Orange bars for gas usage. ‚Ä¢ Grey line for temperature. ‚Ä¢ Dual Y-axes: left for therms, right for temperature. ‚Ä¢ "E" labels above each bar for estimated readings. # Distribution & Trends : ‚Ä¢ Gas usage is lowest in summer months (Jun‚ÄìSep), increases in winter (Dec‚ÄìFeb), then decreases again in spring. ‚Ä¢ Temperature is highest in summer, lowest in winter, and follows an inverse pattern to gas usage. # Analysis : ‚Ä¢ There is a clear inverse relationship between temperature and gas usage: as temperature drops in winter, gas usage rises, likely due to heating needs. ‚Ä¢ All readings are estimated ("E"). ‚Ä¢ The seasonal pattern is consistent, with gas usage peaking during the coldest months and dropping during warmer periods. Summary : This informational box explains how gas usage is measured and converted for billing, and provides a relatable example for understanding a therm of energy. infobox: Heading : Explaining gas charges ‚Ä¢ Gas usage is measured in cubic feet (CCF) and then converted to therms. ‚Ä¢ A standard gas clothes dryer would take about 6 hours of operation to use 1 therm of energy. Icon & Layout : ‚Ä¢ Contains a droplet icon to the left of the example. ‚Ä¢ Text is organized in two paragraphs: the first explains measurement and conversion, the second gives a practical example. Analysis : ‚Ä¢ The box clarifies the units and conversion process for gas billing, and contextualizes energy usage with a household appliance example for customer understanding. # Price to compare If you want to consider getting your gas supply from another supplier, you can compare their price with ours. This month, your cost for gas supply is $5.70 (or an average of 0.32011681 per therm). This price to compare varies from month to month, depending on your usage. **Your PoD ID is: PG000008975075679777** ‚Äì Your PoD ID is your Point of Delivery identification within PSE&G‚Äôs system. You will need this number if you are considering enrolling with another supplier. Summary : This figure presents a dual-axis bar and line chart showing average daily electric usage (kWh) and average daily temperature (¬∞F) from June 2019 to June 2020, alongside the total electric charges of $46.42. bar and line chart: # Title & Axes : ‚Ä¢ Title: "How much electric are you using?" and "Total electric charges $46.42". ‚Ä¢ X-axis: Months from June 2019 to June 2020 (labels: Jun 2019, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct, Nov, Dec, Jan 2020, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun 2020). ‚Ä¢ Left Y-axis: kWh (range: 0 to 20). ‚Ä¢ Right Y-axis: Temperature (¬∞F, range: 0¬∞ to 80¬∞). # Data Points : ‚Ä¢ Series 1 (orange bars, "Average daily usage"): ‚Äì Jun 2019: ~5 kWh ‚Äì Jul: ~13 kWh ‚Äì Aug: ~18 kWh ‚Äì Sep: ~10 kWh ‚Äì Oct: ~6 kWh ‚Äì Nov: ~6 kWh ‚Äì Dec: ~7 kWh ‚Äì Jan 2020: ~8 kWh ‚Äì Feb: ~8 kWh ‚Äì Mar: ~7 kWh ‚Äì Apr: ~7 kWh ‚Äì May: ~7 kWh ‚Äì Jun 2020: ~10 kWh ‚Ä¢ Series 2 (grey line, "Average daily temperature"): ‚Äì Peaks in Jul‚ÄìAug (~80¬∞F), declines to ~40¬∞F by Jan‚ÄìFeb, rises again to ~70¬∞F by Jun 2020. # Design Encodings : ‚Ä¢ Orange bars for electric usage. ‚Ä¢ Grey line for temperature. ‚Ä¢ Dual Y-axes: left for kWh, right for temperature (¬∞F). ‚Ä¢ Legend: orange square for "Average daily usage", grey line for "Average daily temperature", "E" for "Estimated reading" (no estimated readings marked in the visible data). # Distribution & Trends : ‚Ä¢ Electric usage peaks in summer months (Jul‚ÄìAug), drops in fall/winter, rises again in late spring. ‚Ä¢ Temperature follows a similar seasonal pattern, peaking in summer, lowest in winter. # Analysis : ‚Ä¢ There is a clear correlation between higher temperatures and increased electric usage, likely due to air conditioning in summer. ‚Ä¢ Electric usage is lowest during cooler months (Oct‚ÄìApr), when temperature is also lowest. ‚Ä¢ The total electric charges for the period shown is $46.42, suggesting the usage pattern directly impacts billing. ‚Ä¢ No estimated readings are indicated in the chart. Visit MyAccount for more details regarding your energy usage. Explaining electric charges We charge for the electric you use in kilowatt hours (kWh). 1 kilowatt is equal to 1,000 watts. If you use a standard LCD TV which uses ~150 watts while operating, it would take 7 hours of use to equal 1 kWh. # Price to compare If you want to consider getting your electric supply from another supplier, compare their price with ours. This month, your cost for energy supply is $29.71 (or an average of 0.124832 per kWh). This price to compare varies month to month, depending on your usage. Your PoD ID is: PE000008975076479777 ‚Äì Your PoD ID is your Point of Delivery identification within PSE&G‚Äôs system. You will need this number if you are considering enrolling with another supplier. Page 4 of 4

chunks.text:
logo: PSEG (Public Service Enterprise Group) with tagline "We make things work for you."
  Graphic Elements :
    ‚Ä¢ Circular orange emblem with white radiating lines resembling a sunburst, positioned to the left.
    ‚Ä¢ Bold black text "PSEG" with a smaller ampersand (&) between "S" and "G".
    ‚Ä¢ Tagline in italicized font below the company name: "We make things work for you."
  Layout & Dimensions :
    ‚Ä¢ Emblem and text are horizontally aligned.
    ‚Ä¢ Tagline is directly beneath the company name, left-justified.
  Analysis :
    ‚Ä¢ The sunburst emblem suggests energy or power, aligning with PSEG‚Äôs identity as an energy company.
    ‚Ä¢ The use of bold and italic fonts differentiates the company name from the tagline, enhancing brand recognition.

Total amount due: $67.09

Please pay by: July 6, 2020
Your energy bill

! Message Center

This bill reflects changes in the Supply and Delivery portions of your bill, effective June 1, 2020. The change in the Supply portion of your bill is a result of the statewide supply auction that was approved by the BPU on February 5, 2020. The change in the Delivery portion of your bill is a result of a small decrease to the Non-Utility Generation Charge. As a result of these changes, a typical residential customer who receives electric supply from PSE&G and uses 6,920 kilowatt-hours per year will see an average monthly increase of $5.57 or 4.1%. Tariff information may also be found by visiting pseg.com.

Your safety is our top priority. Know what to do if you smell gas.
Natural gas smells like rotten eggs. If you smell gas, leave the area immediately, and call 911 or PSE&G at 800-880-PSEG. Learn more at pseg.com/gassafety.

# Message Center (Continued from page 1)

Si desea recibir en espa√±ol una notificaci√≥n de desconexi√≥n del servicio, llame al **1-800-357-2262**.
If you or a member of your household rely on electricity to operate life sustaining equipment, please notify PSE&G. For more information, visit **pseg.com/life** or call **1-800-436-PSEG**.

There is still time to get help paying your energy bills. Apply for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP). Submit a program application online, by fax, or through the mail by July 31, 2020. Call 1-800-510-3102, or visit pseg.com/help to find out where to apply.

PSE&G can help you save energy and money with rebates of up to $100 on smart thermostats. A smart thermostat can help reduce energy bills by up to 10% annually, and many offer on-the-go control from a smartphone or tablet. Install a smart thermostat in your home and start saving this summer! To learn more, go to pseg.com/marketplace1.

Don't miss your meter reading

If you'll be away on your meter reading day, log in to MyAccount at pseg.com or call 1-800-622-0197 before your scheduled date, to submit your reading.

Electric & Gas Rate Information

For news about PSE&G's rate filing and upcoming public hearings visit www.pseg.com/pseandgfilings. Under applicable tax law, the State Sales and Use Tax and corporate business tax are imposed upon the energy you have used.
Page 2 of 4

bar and line chart:
# Title & Axes :
  ‚Ä¢ Title: "How much gas are you using?"
  ‚Ä¢ Left Y-axis: Therms (average daily usage, range: 0 to 8)
  ‚Ä¢ Right Y-axis: Temperature (average daily temperature, range: 0¬∞ to 80¬∞)

# Data Points :

# Design Encodings :

# Distribution & Trends :
  ‚Ä¢ Gas usage is lowest in summer months (Jun‚ÄìSep), increases in winter (Dec‚ÄìFeb), then decreases again in spring.

# Analysis :
  ‚Ä¢ There is a clear inverse relationship between temperature and gas usage: as temperature drops in winter, gas usage rises, likely due to heating needs.

  ‚Ä¢ The seasonal pattern is consistent, with gas usage peaking during the coldest months and dropping during warmer periods.

Visit MyAccount for more details regarding your energy usage.

Explaining electric charges

We charge for the electric you use in kilowatt hours (kWh). 1 kilowatt is equal to 1,000 watts.

      If you use a standard LCD TV which uses ~150 watts while operating, it would take 7 hours of use to equal 1 kWh.
